Unsealed Court Records Detail How Major Social Media Platforms Targeted Teen Engagement Despite Known Harms
item.description:
The Tech Oversight Project released a detailed report based on newly unsealed court documents from the 2026 federal social media addiction litigation, MDL No. 3047. The materials include internal emails, strategy presentations, expert reports, and executive depositions from Meta, Google/YouTube, Snap, and TikTok. Collectively, the documents indicate that attracting and retaining children and teenagers was a central business objective for these companies, even as internal research acknowledged risks to youth mental health, learning, sleep, and overall well-being.
According to the report, Meta documents describe coordinated strategies to grow teen usage through school-based tactics, ambassador programs, and product features designed to increase habitual engagement. Internal discussions acknowledged correlations between platform use and lower well-being among teens, while still emphasizing the long-term financial value of acquiring users at very young ages. item.title: GNU Hurd Makes Significant Progress in 2026 With 64-bit Support, SMP Improvements, and Growing Debian Compatibility
item.description:
GNU Hurd, the long-standing microkernel-based operating system of the GNU Project, has reached an important milestone in its development, according to a status update presented at FOSDEM 2026 by developer Samuel Thibault. The presentation highlighted tangible progress that makes the system more usable and relevant than in previous years, particularly in areas where Hurd has historically lagged behind Linux and other modern kernels.
One of the most notable achievements is the near-completion of the x86_64 port. For many years, GNU Hurd was largely limited to 32-bit x86 systems, which severely constrained its practicality on modern hardware. With 64-bit support now essentially complete, Hurd can better target contemporary PCs and servers. In addition, there are early discussions and interest in extending support to AArch64, which would further broaden its hardware reach.

item.title: Candace Cameron Bure Affirms Ongoing Support for Lori Loughlin Amid Separation
item.description: Candace Cameron Bure, best known for her role in Full House, has publicly affirmed her continued friendship and support for Lori Loughlin during a challenging period in Loughlin's personal life. Loughlin, 61, is reportedly navigating a separation from her husband, Mossimo Giannulli, after nearly 28 years of marriage. The couple, who share two daughters, Olivia Jade and Isabella Rose, had faced legal issues following the 2019 college admissions scandal, which saw Loughlin serve two months in prison and Giannulli five. Sources suggest that the couple's relationship never fully recovered after the legal fallout, and they are now living separate lives with distinct emotional states. During this time, Bure has remained a steadfast friend, staying in touch and offering both private and public support, referring to Loughlin as 'family.' item.title: Chase Sapphire Cardholders Get Early Access to FIFA World Cup 2026 Tickets in U.S. Cities
item.description:
Chase Sapphire cardholders will soon have a dedicated opportunity to purchase tickets for the FIFA World Cup 2026 matches hosted in the United States. According to the report, starting on February 10, 2026, eligible cardmembers—including those with the Chase Sapphire Reserve, Chase Sapphire Preferred, Chase Sapphire Reserve for Business, and J.P. Morgan Reserve—will be able to directly buy tickets through a special access link. This offer is notable because it is not a lottery-based system; instead, tickets will be sold on a first-come, first-served basis while supplies last.
The ticket sales window is expected to run from February 10 through February 24, 2026, though availability may end earlier due to limited inventory. Only Category 1 and Category 2 seats will be offered, which historically have been among the most expensive options. item.title: Major Tech Stocks Decline Amid Rising AI Investment Costs
item.description: On February 8, 2026, the stock market experienced significant declines as major technology companies faced skepticism over their massive investments in artificial intelligence. Amazon saw its valuation drop by $200 billion in a single session, with shares falling more than 9%. Microsoft suffered its largest one-day decline in over five years, losing roughly $357 billion after announcing record AI investments alongside slower growth in its cloud business. Similarly, Alphabet and Nvidia each lost over $100 billion in market capitalization, reflecting concerns about whether the massive AI spending will translate into profits. Despite these setbacks, investments in AI are projected to increase by 50% this year. Analysts warn that while AI has potential, the enormous capital expenditures required for building large data centers and integrating AI into products create significant financial risks. The developments underscore growing market skepticism about the profitability of AI-focused vent

item.title: Trump Voter Expresses Regret Over Support Amid Controversies and Policy Criticism
item.description: As dissatisfaction with President Donald Trump grows, some of his supporters are publicly expressing regret. One voter from New Mexico, identified only as 'John,' called C-SPAN's 'Washington Journal' to apologize for supporting Trump in three consecutive elections. He criticized the president for posting a racist video on Truth Social featuring former President Barack Obama and Michelle Obama, calling it embarrassing and dishonorable. John also condemned Trump's relationships with corporate leaders, alleged corruption, and harsh immigration enforcement policies, including raids targeting children and schools. Public frustration with Trump extends beyond isolated incidents, reflected in polling showing Americans are unhappy with his authoritarian tendencies, handling of the economy, and focus on conspiracy theories rather than domestic issues. item.title: How Travelers Are Earning American Airlines Status and Navigating Credit Card Changes in 2026
item.description:
This Week in Review from Frequent Miler focuses on how loyalty programs and credit card strategies are evolving in 2026, with particular attention to American Airlines AAdvantage. The article opens with a discussion of modern “mileage running,” explaining how elite status can now be earned without flying. Since American Airlines awards Loyalty Points for credit card spending, shopping portals, hotel bookings, and other partnerships, travelers close to an elite threshold can finish qualifying from home. The author describes using AAdvantage Shopping and tax payments on credit cards to bridge the gap between Gold and Platinum status, while also clarifying timing rules around February transactions and statement closing dates.

item.title: Notable human-interest stories this week: Nepal rescue fraud and contrasting teenage acts of risk and bravery
item.description:
This Saturday Selection article from Frequent Miler highlights several unusual and human-interest news stories that caught the editors’ attention during the week. Rather than focusing on travel rewards or credit cards, the piece curates stories that are striking, ironic, or emotionally compelling.
The first story centers on a large-scale fraud involving helicopter rescue operations in Nepal. Because trekking at high altitudes is dangerous, hikers are typically required to have insurance that covers emergency rescues, which are common and extremely costly. According to the article, several travel and rescue executives allegedly exploited this system by submitting fabricated rescue claims. These claims reportedly included fake hospital documents, medical invoices, and cargo manifests. Authorities arrested six executives, with one company accused of filing 171 fraudulent claims out of more than 1,200 submissions, leading to over $10 million in illegitimate insurance payouts. item.title: Monica Lewinsky Reflects on the Lasting Emotional Impact of the 1998 Clinton Scandal
item.description: Nearly three decades after the 1998 scandal involving then-President Bill Clinton, Monica Lewinsky continues to discuss the deep emotional impact it has had on her life. In a recent episode of her podcast, Reclaiming with Monica Lewinsky, she spoke with actress Jameela Jamil about the lingering fear and anxiety stemming from the intense public scrutiny she experienced. Lewinsky explained that although she has made progress in healing and has become more confident in her identity, the fear of losing everything she has built remains a constant presence. She described moments of vulnerability, feeling as though the trauma from the past could resurface at any time and threaten her sense of purpose and stability. Despite these challenges, Lewinsky emphasized her efforts to stay grounded in the present and focus on what she has now rather than what happened decades ago. item.title: U.S. Trade Deficit and the Impact of Tariffs on Imports
item.description: The article discusses recent trends in the U.S. trade deficit, illustrated with graphs from WolfStreet. It highlights that the temporary spike in the deficit was largely due to U.S. importers stockpiling goods in anticipation of new tariffs. While the tariffs have indeed discouraged imports, the article argues that a significant portion of the adjustment in the trade balance, particularly with Europe, is influenced by broader geopolitical events. The post controversially suggests that the war in Ukraine has had economic repercussions that affected trade flows. The author briefly notes personal engagement with a small online group but does not elaborate further. Overall, the article provides an economic commentary linking U.S. trade policy, import behavior, and international relations, without delving into in-depth statistical analysis or offering comprehensive policy evaluation.

item.title: State-Supported Displacement of Palestinians in the West Bank Intensifies
item.description: Over the past several years, the forced displacement of Palestinians in the West Bank has intensified dramatically, evolving from sporadic settler encroachment into a coordinated, state-backed campaign. The Naasan family exemplifies this crisis: they have been forcibly uprooted twice from their ancestral lands in the Jordan Valley due to violent attacks by Israeli settlers and military forces. Settler raids, home demolitions, and systemic harassment continue to target Palestinian communities, particularly Bedouin villages in Area C, leading to widespread displacement. Since October 2023, tens of thousands of Palestinians have been internally displaced, including over 30,000 from refugee camps during large-scale military operations. The displacement is accompanied by property destruction, killing of livestock, and direct threats to civilians. Experts describe these actions as deliberate demographic engineering, supported by Israeli government funding and quasi-governmental organizations

item.title: An Overview of French Comics Artist Serge Pellé and His Science Fiction Work on Orbital
item.description:
This article from the Lines and Colors blog presents an overview of the work of French comics artist Serge Pellé, best known for his contributions to the science fiction comic series 'Orbital,' created in collaboration with writer Sylvain Runberg. The post situates Pellé within the contemporary European comics scene, emphasizing his distinctive visual style and his ability to construct dramatic, immersive futuristic environments.
Pellé’s artwork is characterized by expansive science fiction settings rendered with deep perspective and a high level of architectural and mechanical detail. The article highlights his talent for depicting large-scale futuristic structures, imaginative spacecraft, and alien creatures, all enhanced by intense lighting and dynamic compositions. These elements combine to create scenes that feel cinematic and atmospheric, reinforcing the narrative tension of the Orbital series.

item.title: Viking-Age Mass Grave Near Cambridge Reveals Trepanned Skull of Exceptionally Tall Young Man
item.description:
Archaeologists working near Cambridge, UK, have uncovered a highly unusual Viking-era mass grave dating to the 9th century, a period marked by sustained conflict following the Viking conquest of the region in 870 A.D. The burial pit was found just south of the Iron Age hillfort at Wandlebury and contains the remains of up to ten young men. The site is located in what was once a volatile frontier zone between the Saxon kingdoms of Mercia and East Anglia, an area frequently contested during the early Viking presence in England.
The grave is striking for the chaotic and violent nature of the burial. It includes at least four complete skeletons that appear to have been bound at the time of burial, with dismembered body parts—such as stacked legs, scattered limbs, and a pile of skulls—thrown on top of them. item.title: Epic Games Store Offers Two Free Games This Week
item.description: Epic Games Store continues its tradition of offering free games to its users, doubling the number of free titles compared to the previous week. From February 5 to February 12, 2026, players can claim two new free games that will permanently belong to their accounts once registered. The first game, Botany Manor, is a first-person puzzle adventure set on a Victorian English estate in 1890. Players take on the role of botanist Arabella Greene, exploring the estate and learning how to cultivate extraordinary plants. The second free game, Poison Retro Set, is a vibrant action-adventure shooter inspired by retro arcade aesthetics. It features both single-player and online multiplayer modes, including cooperative and cross-platform play, with neon visuals and intense gameplay reminiscent of Pixel Gun 3D. This initiative by Epic Games Store highlights its commitment to providing valuable free content for gamers, keeping the weekly game giveaways as a staple for its platform users.

item.title: China Expands Tariff-Free Access for South African Exports Amid Trade Tensions With the United States
item.description:
The article analyzes the growing trade and diplomatic tensions between South Africa and the United States, and how China has stepped in as an alternative economic partner for Pretoria. Relations between South Africa and Washington have cooled due to political disagreements, South Africa’s positions on sensitive international issues, and its participation in alliances such as BRICS, which challenge U.S. global influence. As a result, the United States has threatened South Africa’s trade privileges and imposed tariffs on key exports, negatively affecting an economy already vulnerable to global instability.
In response, South Africa has accelerated a strategy aimed at reducing its dependence on the U.S. market while diversifying its trade partnerships. China has emerged as a central player in this shift. Beijing has decided to grant tariff-free access to specific South African products, offering immediate relief to exporters harmed by U.S. tariffs. item.title: U.S. Government Refuses to Re-admit College Student Deported Despite Court Order
item.description: In a recent legal development in Massachusetts, the U.S. federal government has declined to reinstate 19-year-old college student Lucia Lopez Belloza, who was deported to Honduras in November despite a court order preventing her removal. U.S. District Judge Richard G. Stearns had initially blocked her deportation and recommended that she be issued a student visa to return to the U.S. However, federal prosecutors argue that the Secretary of State does not have the legal authority to grant visas unilaterally. The government further noted that if Lopez Belloza returned, she would still be subject to immediate detention and removal under a final deportation order. ICE confirmed that while they considered returning her to the status quo prior to her removal, they have decided against it. Lopez Belloza, who had no criminal record, expressed that her deportation felt unjust, as she had been focused on her studies and had secured significant financial aid to attend college. item.title: Grif’s Equinox Series Transforms Urban Spaces with Surreal Floral Imagery
item.description: Grif's 'Equinox' series explores the intersection of urban environments and nature through digital surrealism. The collection imagines cities and everyday objects overtaken by botanical growth, creating visually striking scenarios where flowers reclaim asphalt, steel, and architecture. In pieces like 'Going Green,' a sports car in the desert evolves into a miniature ecosystem, while 'Brooklyn Brownstone' reimagines New York’s facades as vertical gardens with climbing vines and blooming morning glories. 'Angels Gate' incorporates a basketball court into this botanical transformation, merging rigid geometry with organic forms. The series also references art history, as seen in a floral reinterpretation of Vermeer’s 'Girl with a Pearl Earring,' where petals replace paint to suggest the freedom of imagination beyond historical constraints. item.title: Magellania: A Hardcore Space Tactics RPG Released on Steam
item.description: Magellania is a turn-based tactics RPG developed and published by Illunsoft, released on March 18, 2021, with an Early Access version from January 27, 2021. The game features a unique storyline where Prince Lofty of Pluto, after being snubbed by other planetary rulers on his birthday, decides to invade their kingdoms. Players travel across a reimagined Solar System, assembling a team from diverse classes to defeat enemy factions. Magellania emphasizes strategic combat, with randomized badge drops, a combo-based damage system, and action commands. Players can collect CDs to change in-game music, experiment with team compositions, and unlock postgame content. The game supports single-player mode, Steam Achievements, and is available in English. Reviews are positive, with 100% of 33 user reviews rating the game favorably. System requirements are modest, making it accessible to a wide range of players. item.title: Kim Kardashian Confirms She and Kanye West Remain Family Amid Apology and Co-Parenting
item.description: Kim Kardashian addressed her relationship with her ex-husband Kanye West, now known as Ye, following his public apology for past antisemitic remarks. In the apology, printed in The Wall Street Journal, Ye attributed some of his behavior to a 2002 car accident that caused a brain injury and potentially worsened his bipolar disorder, diagnosed in 2016. Despite their divorce in 2022, Kardashian emphasized that they remain committed co-parents to their four children: North, 12, Saint, 10, Chicago, 8, and Psalm, 6. She reaffirmed their family bond, stating, “We’ll always be family,” and expressed her focus on stability and love for their children. Kardashian also praised a pair of Yeezy boots in a TikTok video, noting their style and personal significance. Ye’s apology letter detailed his mental health struggles, including a manic episode that led to destructive actions, and he expressed deep remorse for his past antisemitic behavior, emphasizing accountability and meaningful change. item.title: Trump Faces Backlash After Sharing Racist AI-Generated Image of the Obamas on Truth Social
item.description:
US President Donald Trump sparked widespread condemnation after sharing a video on his Truth Social platform that briefly depicted former President Barack Obama and former First Lady Michelle Obama with monkey faces. The one-minute clip, posted on Thursday evening, primarily focused on repeating false claims about alleged irregularities in the 2020 presidential election, particularly questioning President Joe Biden’s victory in Pennsylvania. Near the end of the video, at the 59-second mark, an AI-generated image appeared showing Barack Obama’s face superimposed on a monkey’s body, accompanied by the song “The Lion Sleeps Tonight.”
The post quickly drew criticism across social media platforms, with many users and public figures denouncing it as racist and offensive. California Governor Gavin Newsom, through his press office, described the post as “disgusting behavior” and urged Republicans to publicly denounce it. item.title: India Agrees to End Russian Oil Imports Following U.S. Trade Pressure
item.description: The United States has removed tariffs on Indian imports following India's agreement to halt all direct and indirect purchases of Russian oil. This development comes after months of escalating trade tensions, where U.S. punitive tariffs were imposed to pressure India into aligning its energy policy with American priorities. By agreeing to redirect its energy imports to other countries, particularly the U.S. and Venezuela, India has shifted from its longstanding strategy of diversified energy sourcing and cost prioritization. The move highlights the influence of economic leverage in international relations, signaling that access to major markets often requires political concessions. While India maintains some strategic autonomy, the decision underscores the limits of neutrality when faced with the economic power of a global hegemon. For emerging economies, this case demonstrates that maintaining a neutral position in global energy politics can come with high costs and strategic constrain

item.title: Historical Continuity of State-Sanctioned Violence from the KKK to ICE
item.description: This article draws a historical parallel between the Ku Klux Klan (KKK) and the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), framing both as instruments of state terror designed to divide and control the working class. The KKK emerged after the U.S. Civil War to maintain white supremacy and social order through terror, targeting Black citizens and preventing interracial labor solidarity. The article argues that the KKK’s racial violence was not mere fanaticism but a calculated political tool tolerated or supported by authorities, evolving over time from clandestine operations to infiltrating government structures. ICE, created in 2003 under the Department of Homeland Security, is portrayed as a modern continuation of this model, enforcing xenophobic and anti-labor policies under legal authority. item.title: In-Depth Review of the Alaska Atmos™ Rewards Summit Visa Infinite® Card and Its Long-Term Value
item.description:
The Alaska Atmos™ Rewards Summit Visa Infinite® card is a premium travel credit card with a $395 annual fee that targets frequent Alaska and Hawaiian Airlines flyers, as well as travelers seeking elite status and high-value award redemptions. Its standout feature is an exceptionally strong welcome offer: 100,000 Atmos points plus a 25,000-point Global Companion Award after $6,000 in spend within 90 days. Given an estimated average value of 1.5 cents per point, the welcome bonus alone can be worth roughly $1,875 if fully optimized.
The card earns 3x points on Alaska Airlines, Hawaiian Airlines, dining, and foreign purchases, with 1x on all other spending. It also provides a 10% bonus on earned points for cardholders with eligible Bank of America accounts. Unique benefits include annual Global Companion Awards, which act as discounts on the second passenger’s award ticket, and an additional 100,000-point companion award after $60,000 in annual spend. item.title: The 1842 Revolt of Enslaved African Americans in Cherokee Territory
item.description:
This article examines a little-known episode in United States history: the 1842 rebellion of enslaved African Americans against their Cherokee owners in what was then Indian Territory, present-day Oklahoma. Contrary to the simplified narratives often presented in popular culture, the story reveals the complex and uncomfortable realities of power, oppression, and survival in the American South. During the early nineteenth century, several Native American nations of the Southeast, including the Cherokee, adopted aspects of European-American culture in an effort to avoid displacement. This process of so-called “civilization” included plantation agriculture and the enslavement of Black people.
After the forced removal known as the Trail of Tears, wealthy Cherokee elites rebuilt their plantation economy in Indian Territory, bringing enslaved people with them. item.title: EU prepares framework allowing US access to biometric data for visa-free travel agreements
item.description:
European Union member states are preparing to grant the United States access to national biometric databases containing sensitive personal data, including fingerprints and facial scans, as part of efforts to preserve visa-free travel for EU citizens. Washington has demanded such access since 2022 under what it calls Enhanced Border Security Partnerships (EBSP), linking data-sharing arrangements to continued participation in the US Visa Waiver Program. While most EU countries are affected, Romania, Bulgaria and Cyprus are already excluded from visa-free travel, and Denmark and Ireland will not be bound by the EU framework due to legal opt-outs.
The European Commission is expected to lead negotiations on an overarching EU-US framework that will define general rules for EBSP agreements. item.title: Discussion on January Temperature Drops and Climate Data Reliability
item.description: The article discusses a reported significant drop in global average temperatures in January and challenges the reliability of climate data and models. It references statements made over 20 years ago by climatologist Mojib Latif, who predicted that Germany would no longer experience harsh winters due to global warming, noting that recent severe winter conditions contradict those predictions. The text criticizes climate models like ERA5 and datasets such as HadCRUT for relying on indirect measurements and statistical estimations rather than actual, continuous temperature recordings. The author argues that temperature databases are adjusted over time, sometimes retroactively, to fit prevailing climate narratives, highlighting past controversies including the 2009 East Anglia emails that suggested manipulation of climate records. item.title: Former Canadian military chief raises debate on nuclear deterrence amid strained U.S.–Canada relations
item.description:
The article reports on a controversial debate sparked in Canada following remarks by retired General Wayne Eyre, who served as Chief of the Defence Staff from 2021 to 2024. Speaking at a conference at Ottawa’s Rideau Club, Eyre argued that Canada would never achieve true strategic independence without its own nuclear deterrent. He claimed that Canada possesses many of the prerequisites for such a program, including a strong civilian nuclear industry, scientific expertise, and significant uranium reserves, which rank among the largest in the world.
Eyre emphasized that he was not necessarily calling for the immediate development of nuclear weapons, but rather for keeping all strategic options open. He suggested investing in delivery technologies, particularly in aerospace and missile capabilities, so that Canada could act quickly if future circumstances demanded it. According to Eyre, these steps would provide strategic coverage in an increasingly unstable global environment.

item.title: Montreal Proposes to Host NATO Rearmament Bank Headquarters
item.description: Montreal has officially submitted its candidacy to host the headquarters of the Defense and Security Reinforcement Bank (DSR), an institution aimed at facilitating financing for NATO member countries' rearmament. According to Stéphane Paquet, Director of Montreal International, the city is the only Canadian metropolis that meets all necessary requirements for hosting the future bank. Montreal boasts around 70 international organizations, including six UN offices and NATO’s Climate Change and Security Centre of Excellence, as well as significant experience in aerospace, finance, defense, and technology sectors. The initiative has received support from key local and provincial political figures, including Quebec’s Prime Minister François Legault, Montreal Mayor Soraya Martínez Ferrada, and Minister of International Affairs Christopher Skeete, as well as other political leaders. item.title: Bilt 5x Everywhere Promotion May Not Apply to All New Cardholders: Verify Before Spending
item.description:
The article warns new Bilt credit card holders to verify whether they actually received the highly anticipated 5x points everywhere promotional offer before making any purchases. Bilt is launching its new credit card portfolio, and a subset of applicants—specifically those approved through a limited-time application link shared by The Points Guy—were expected to receive five days of 5x earning on all purchases, capped at 50,000 bonus points. This offer was especially valuable, prompting many cardholders to plan significant spending as soon as their cards became active.
However, reports surfaced indicating that the 5x promotion was not properly attached to all accounts that cardholders believed were eligible. According to Doctor of Credit and multiple user reports, some customers contacted Bilt customer service only to learn that their accounts did not include the 5x bonus, despite applying during the perceived promotional window. item.title: Samsung Slac Concept Reimagines Earbuds as Wearable Jewelry
item.description:
Samsung’s Slac concept explores a future where wearable technology is designed first as an object of personal adornment rather than as a piece of visible consumer electronics. Instead of traditional in-ear earbuds, Slac consists of a circular ear ring paired with a wrist component, both of which resemble contemporary jewelry more than audio devices. The ear ring wraps gently around the ear without entering the ear canal, allowing users to remain aware of conversations, traffic, and environmental sounds while listening to music or other audio content.
A key feature of the design is its modular, case-free approach. When not in use, the ear ring magnetically attaches to the wrist piece, transforming into a bracelet-like form. This eliminates the need for a separate charging or storage case and reinforces the idea that the product is meant to be worn continuously, like jewelry. item.title: New DOJ records raise unresolved questions about activity near Jeffrey Epstein’s jail cell before his death
item.description:
Newly released Department of Justice documents have revived questions about the circumstances surrounding Jeffrey Epstein’s death in a federal jail in August 2019, focusing on unexplained activity near his cell hours before he was found dead. Surveillance video logs reviewed by investigators describe an orange-colored figure ascending the staircase to Epstein’s isolated housing tier at approximately 10:39 p.m. the night before his body was discovered. This observation appears to contradict repeated official statements that no one entered the tier that night.
The records show that different investigative bodies interpreted the same blurry video footage in conflicting ways. FBI reviewers suggested the figure could have been an inmate wearing an orange prison uniform, while the Justice Department’s Office of the Inspector General concluded it was an unidentified corrections officer possibly carrying orange linen or bedding. item.title: HBO Develops ‘Baldur’s Gate’ Series as Direct Sequel to Baldur’s Gate 3 with Craig Mazin as Showrunner
item.description:
HBO is developing a television adaptation of the acclaimed video game Baldur’s Gate 3, with Craig Mazin—best known for co-creating HBO’s The Last of Us—attached as creator, writer, executive producer, and showrunner. Unlike many video game adaptations that retell existing stories, the Baldur’s Gate series will serve as a direct continuation of the game’s narrative, taking place immediately after the events of Baldur’s Gate 3. The story will explore the consequences of the game’s ending while introducing new protagonists who must navigate a world shaped by the actions of powerful, established characters.
The series is being produced in collaboration with Hasbro Entertainment, with additional executive producers including Jacqueline Lesko, Cecil O’Connor, and Hasbro’s Gabriel Marano. Chris Perkins, former Head of Story at Wizards of the Coast, will act as a consultant to ensure fidelity to Dungeons & Dragons lore. item.title: Some Barclays American Airlines cards will remain with Barclays and be converted to non-AA products
item.description:
The article explains an unexpected development in the transition of Barclays-issued American Airlines credit cards to Citibank. While most Barclays AAdvantage cardholders were informed that their accounts would move to Citi on April 24, making Citi the exclusive U.S. issuer of American Airlines credit cards, a subset of customers received a different notice. These cardholders were told that their cards would remain with Barclays instead of transferring to Citi.
Because Barclays will no longer be permitted to issue American Airlines–branded cards, affected accounts will be product-changed into other Barclays cards. Personal Aviator Red and Silver cards are being converted into the Barclays Arrival Plus Mastercard, while Aviator Business cards are being converted into the Barclays Juniper Business Mastercard. item.title: Pentagon Threatens to End Partnership with Scouting America Over Inclusive Policies Including Girls' Participation
item.description: The Pentagon, under the Trump administration and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, has issued a warning to Scouting America (formerly known as the Boy Scouts of America) threatening to sever its long-standing military partnership and withdraw financial and logistical support unless the organization reverses its inclusive policies. This includes demands to abandon diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) initiatives, 'gender-fluid ideological stances,' and specifically the admission of girls, which began in Cub Scouts in 2018 and expanded to the main program in 2019, along with prior changes allowing LGBTQ+ youth and leaders. Pentagon spokesperson Sean Parnell posted on social media that the group has 'lost its way' since its 2025 rebrand to promote inclusivity, deviating from 'core values' aligned with 'God and country.' item.title: Innovative Design of the Veluwemeer Aqueduct in the Netherlands
item.description: The Veluwemeer Aqueduct in the Netherlands presents an innovative approach to bridge design that flips traditional expectations. Unlike conventional bridges where roads go over water, this aqueduct allows a road to pass underneath a waterway. Boats can travel smoothly across the shallow channel on top while cars drive below without interruption. This design eliminates the need for drawbridges, tall structures, or any waiting times for passing vessels, creating a seamless flow of both road and water traffic. The structure highlights a minimalist and efficient engineering approach, characteristic of Dutch design thinking, where water is integrated into infrastructure rather than treated as an obstacle. Its clever design initially causes a mental double-take, as viewers instinctively perceive water above a road as impossible. item.title: U.S. Dealers Express Concern Over Potential Entry of Chinese Automakers
item.description: The potential entry of Chinese automakers into the U.S. market has sparked strong reactions from American car dealers. Following Canada’s recent approval for Chinese cars, the National Automobile Dealers Association (NADA) has voiced deep concerns. CEO Mike Stanton warned that allowing Chinese vehicles could be detrimental to the U.S. automotive industry, consumers, and the country’s economic interests. While some members of Congress, such as Ohio Senator Bernie Moreno, reportedly support resisting Chinese imports, there is bipartisan acknowledgment of the challenges posed by the direct-to-consumer sales model favored by Chinese manufacturers. Analysts suggest that the resistance from NADA is largely tied to the existing dealership franchise system, which Chinese automakers might bypass by selling directly to consumers and offering lower prices. item.description:
This Frequent Miler On The Air podcast episode focuses on an in-depth comparison of airline credit cards with annual fees around $350, specifically those offered by American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines, and Alaska Airlines. A significant portion of the episode is dedicated to lounge access policies, elite-status-related perks, and how each card supports travelers who are chasing or maintaining airline status.

item.title: Claims and Counterclaims Over the Destruction of a Russian Olymp (Luch) Satellite Amid Rising Space Tensions
item.description:
The article reports that a Russian satellite of the Olymp (also known as Luch) series was destroyed on January 30, allegedly by U.S. Space Force anti-satellite capabilities, presenting the event as one of the first kinetic actions in orbit linked to the broader context of the war in Ukraine. At the same time, it acknowledges that alternative explanations exist, with some outlets suggesting the satellite may have broken apart due to an accidental collision with space debris rather than a deliberate military strike.
The Olymp/Luch satellites, launched beginning in 2014, have long drawn attention from Western governments because of what they describe as unusual behavior. According to Western sources cited in the article, these satellites frequently maneuvered within the geostationary belt and approached communications satellites operated by other countries. Customers who deposit between $2,000 and $19,999 within 30 days of account enrollment can earn a $300 bonus, while those depositing $20,000 or more can earn $750. The deposited funds must remain in the account for at least 60 days from enrollment, and customers must also complete five qualifying transactions within 90 days.
Qualifying transactions include debit card purchases, ACH credits, wire transfers, Chase QuickDeposit, Chase Online Bill Pay, and QuickAccept payments. Notably, the offer does not require direct deposit, which makes it easier than many competing bank bonuses. After all requirements are met, Chase deposits the bonus within 15 days.

item.title: Criticism of Western-Led Peace Negotiations and Ceasefire Proposals in the Ukraine War
item.description:
The article presents a highly critical interpretation of recent diplomatic efforts involving the United States, Ukraine, and the European Union to negotiate a peace agreement with Russia. According to the author, talks held in Paris focused on conditions that Russia has consistently rejected, while deliberately excluding issues Moscow considers essential. This approach, the article argues, makes a genuine peace agreement impossible and instead serves a political objective: prolonging the conflict while portraying Russia as inherently hostile to peace.
A central argument is that European and US proposals assume from the outset that Russia would violate any future agreement. On that basis, Western actors emphasize the need for so-called security guarantees for Ukraine. The article questions the logic of signing an agreement that is presumed to be broken, suggesting that such guarantees would function as a pretext for rapid Western military intervention in Ukraine. item.description:

As TikTok’s algorithm continues to prioritize authentic engagement, creators are encouraged to focus on tools and platforms that help them connect with real users who care about their content.
Several growth services are reviewed, starting with HighSocial, which is presented as the strongest option overall. HighSocial focuses on intelligent targeting, allowing creators to define their ideal audience by interests, age, location, and niche. Its approach aims to deliver real followers, save creators time, and support long-term community building through automated yet organic promotion.

item.title: Analysis of Spain's Social Media Ban: Risks, Privacy Concerns, and Alternatives
item.description: The Spanish Government has announced a ban on social media access for individuals under 16, citing child protection as the main reason. However, critics argue the measure is largely ineffective and poses serious risks to privacy and civil liberties. Social media companies prioritize advertising revenue over user well-being, designing platforms to maximize engagement, often to the detriment of mental health. Measures like hiding 'likes' could reduce harm without restricting access, but governments often avoid these less disruptive alternatives due to economic interests. Prohibiting access entirely can hinder freedom of expression, access to information, and social development, especially for marginalized groups or individuals with dissident sexual and gender identities. Age verification systems, required for enforcement, would create centralized databases linking civil identities to online activity, increasing cybercrime risks and eliminating anonymity that historically protects dissent

item.title: Russian General Vladimir Alexeiev Wounded in Moscow Attack
item.description: On the morning of February 6, 2026, a terrorist attack occurred on the stairs of a residential building near Moscow targeting General Vladimir Alexeiev of the Russian army. The attacker fired multiple shots at Alexeiev's back. He was immediately taken to a nearby hospital, where he underwent surgery and remains in a coma. Alexeiev, of Ukrainian origin, is the deputy director of Russia's military intelligence agency, GRU, oversees the country's private military companies, and was involved in negotiations during the Wagner Group mutiny in 2023. He is also under U.S. and U.K. sanctions for alleged involvement in election interference and the 2018 Salisbury poisoning incident. The attack coincides with the start of trilateral peace talks in Abu Dhabi, in which his superior, Igor Kostyukov, is participating. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov blamed Ukraine for attempting to disrupt the negotiations. Ukraine has reportedly targeted at least three Russian generals near Moscow in the past

item.description: On February 5, 2026, American Express updated the public welcome offer for the consumer American Express Platinum Card®. The key change is an increase in the minimum spending requirement to earn the signup bonus, rising 50% from $8,000 to $12,000 within the first 6 months. The bonus itself remains unchanged at as high as 175,000 Membership Rewards points, though actual offers vary by applicant and are only revealed after applying. This adjustment marks a notable shift, as it is uncommon for issuers to raise spend thresholds without boosting the points awarded. item.title: Fatal EV Fire Highlights Safety Risks of Retractable Door Handles in China
item.description:
A recently resurfaced viral video has reignited debate around vehicle safety after showing the dramatic rescue of three passengers from a burning electric sedan in China. The incident involved a Dongfeng eπ007 electric car that crashed in Wenshan, Yunnan province, on March 19, 2025, following a high-speed collision with a truck. Although the crash itself did not initially appear severe, the vehicle’s battery was apparently punctured, triggering a fire less than a minute after impact.
The video shows the driver exiting the car quickly but being unable to open the rear door because the retractable door handles failed to deploy. Moments later, even the driver’s own door became inoperable. Within 29 seconds, smoke filled the cabin, trapping three passengers inside as all doors remained shut. With time running out, the driver attempted to break the window using his elbow, while a bystander rushed in to help. Using rocks, they smashed the side windows and managed to pull two occupants free.

item.title: Cannabis Use in Adults 40-77 Linked to Brain Volume and Cognitive Performance, Study Shows
item.description: A recent study conducted by researchers at CU Anschutz explored the impact of cannabis use on the brains of middle-aged and older adults. Unlike most research that focuses on adolescents, this investigation analyzed data from 26,362 participants aged 40 to 77 using the UK Biobank. The study found that moderate cannabis usage was generally associated with larger volumes in several brain regions, particularly those with high cannabinoid receptor density, and better performance in cognitive tasks such as learning, memory, attention, processing speed, and executive function. Interestingly, while most regions showed positive associations, the posterior cingulate area displayed lower volume in high-use participants, highlighting the complexity of cannabis effects. Sex differences were observed, with nuanced interactions suggesting the endocannabinoid system functions differently in men and women. item.description:
Representative Ro Khanna of California said the U.S. Department of Justice’s latest release of records related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, while significant, falls short of full transparency. Speaking Sunday on NBC News’ “Meet the Press,” Khanna argued that the disclosure does not meet the public’s demand for accountability and warned that further congressional action could follow if all remaining files are not released.
According to Khanna, the Justice Department identified more than 6 million documents connected to the Epstein case but released only about 3 to 3.5 million after review and redactions. Although he acknowledged that the newly disclosed records were substantial and troubling, he emphasized that they represent only roughly half of the total materials collected. item.title: Kansas Farmers Face Labor Shortages from Immigration Enforcement and Trade Issues, Risking Crop Losses and Economic Damage
item.description: Kansas farmers are sounding the alarm over severe labor shortages triggered by intensified immigration enforcement, leading to sudden departures of immigrant workers essential for harvesting. Many report entire crews vanishing overnight due to fears of detention or deportation, leaving crops like carrots unharvested and valued at nearly $1 million in some cases. This threatens contract fulfillment, potential legal actions, and even bankruptcy for affected producers, as experienced manual labor cannot be easily replaced. The issue extends beyond fields to meat and livestock processing plants, where worker shortages could slow production, reduce supply, and increase nationwide consumer prices. Compounding these challenges are persistent trade disruptions, including lost export markets to China for soybeans and wheat, resulting in excess supply, depressed prices, and weakened long-term trade relationships despite temporary aid promises. item.description:
During a U.S. Senate antitrust hearing examining Netflix’s proposed acquisition of Warner Bros. Discovery’s studio and streaming assets, Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) launched a pointed critique of the company’s inclusion of transgender and LGBTQ+ characters, particularly in content accessible to children. Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos firmly rejected the assertion, stating that the figures were inaccurate and that he had no idea where they originated.
Hawley appeared to rely on claims from the conservative advocacy group Concerned Women for America, which previously asserted that 41% of certain children’s-rated Netflix series contain LGBTQ+ content. item.description:

According to Finland’s public broadcaster Yle, the objective is not merely to renovate the abandoned site but to fully reactivate it as part of Russia’s broader defensive posture toward NATO. The base is located near Petrozavodsk, the regional capital, only a few dozen kilometers from Finnish territory, making it strategically significant.
In recent weeks, the site has undergone rapid changes. New infrastructure has been built, military equipment has been transported in, and terrain preparation work has intensified. Areas that were previously forested have been cleared, the land has been leveled, and military trucks have begun rotating through the base. item.title: Methuselah, the Ancient Bristlecone Pine That Reveals Millennia of Earth’s History
item.description:
High in California’s White Mountains stands Methuselah, an ancient bristlecone pine widely recognized as one of the oldest living organisms on Earth. Estimated to be over 4,800 years old, this remarkable tree has been alive since before the construction of the Great Pyramids of Egypt, quietly enduring vast stretches of human and natural history. Its age and resilience have made it a powerful symbol of longevity and survival in extreme environments.
Methuselah was identified in the 1950s by Edmund Schulman, a dendrochronologist from the University of Arizona, who studied tree rings to understand past climates. Through careful analysis, Schulman determined that this particular bristlecone pine was thousands of years old. To protect it from vandalism and excessive human impact, its precise location within the White Mountains is kept secret.

item.title: Michelangelo's Earliest Known Painting: The Torment of Saint Anthony, Created at Age 12 or 13
item.description: The Torment of Saint Anthony is widely regarded as the earliest surviving painting by Michelangelo Buonarroti, created around 1487–1488 when he was approximately 12 or 13 years old. This work, housed at the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth, Texas, is a tempera and oil on panel piece depicting Saint Anthony the Great being tormented and lifted into the air by a group of grotesque demons. It is based on a 15th-century engraving by the German artist Martin Schongauer titled Saint Anthony Tormented by Demons, but the young Michelangelo transformed it by adding vibrant colors, enhanced textures, and atmospheric depth. According to historical accounts from Giorgio Vasari and Ascanio Condivi—Michelangelo's early biographers—the artist studied real fish specimens at the market to accurately render the scaly, animal-like features of the demons, making them more lifelike and compact than in the original engraving. item.description:
The article reports on the expiration of the START (Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty), the last remaining bilateral arms control agreement between the United States and Russia governing strategic nuclear weapons. The treaty officially expired after Washington failed to respond to a Russian proposal to extend it for one additional year. Russian officials, including Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov and Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov, warned that the absence of the treaty places the world in a more dangerous and unstable situation.
START had long been a cornerstone of global nuclear stability, limiting each country to 1,550 deployed strategic nuclear warheads and establishing verification mechanisms such as mutual inspections and data exchanges. item.title: Hydraulic Cylinder Repair and the Role of Maintenance in Long-Term Machine Performance
item.description:
The article explores longevity not as an accidental outcome, but as a deliberate design and maintenance choice embedded in mechanical systems. It argues that machines, like buildings or tools, are shaped by assumptions about wear, stress, and repeated use. Rather than treating wear as a failure, the text frames it as an expected and measurable result of sustained operation. Polished surfaces, compressed seals, and shifting tolerances are presented as records of work performed, not signs of neglect.
A central theme is that thoughtful design anticipates where and how wear will occur. Engineers decide which components absorb stress and which remain stable, allowing systems to age in controlled and predictable ways. Longevity, therefore, depends less on preventing change and more on managing it within acceptable boundaries. This perspective shifts attention from avoiding wear to designing systems that can be adjusted, repaired, and realigned over time.

item.title: The U.S. War Plan Red and Its Historical Context in U.S.–Canada Relations
item.description:
The article examines War Plan Red, a real military contingency plan developed by the United States between the late 1920s and mid-1930s, which outlined a hypothetical invasion of Canada in the event of a war with the British Empire. Designed in 1927, approved in 1930, and revised in 1935, the plan remained classified until 1974 and reflected interwar strategic thinking rather than an imminent intention to attack Canada. The plan assumed that the United States would quickly neutralize British forces and occupy key Canadian cities, including Halifax, Montreal, Toronto, and Ottawa, to prevent Britain from using Canada as a staging ground.
According to the article, the plan included detailed operational elements such as seizing ports, disrupting infrastructure, and rapidly occupying population centers. item.description:
France has decided to phase out the use of U.S.-based videoconferencing platforms such as Zoom and Microsoft Teams within parts of its public administration, marking a significant step in Europe’s broader push for digital sovereignty. The move reflects growing concern among European governments about reliance on American technology firms for critical digital infrastructure, particularly in areas involving sensitive government communications and data protection.
French authorities are encouraging the adoption of European-developed alternatives that comply more closely with EU data protection rules, including the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Officials argue that even when U.S. companies store data on European servers, they may still be subject to American laws that allow U.S. authorities to access data, raising sovereignty and security concerns. item.title: Architecture That Responds to Light, Air, and Human Experience
item.description:
The article explores the concept of “breathing” as a contemporary architectural design philosophy that emphasizes responsiveness to light, air, movement, and the surrounding environment. Rather than treating buildings as sealed, static objects, breathing spaces are designed as dynamic frameworks that interact continuously with nature and human presence. From the moment one enters such a space, subtle elements—shifting daylight, gentle airflow, softened boundaries between indoors and outdoors—create a sense of calm and vitality.
Central to this approach is the rejection of over-containment. Designers prioritize orientation, openness, and the strategic use of natural light as a core material. Daylight is allowed to define rhythm and mood throughout the day, while shadows, reflections, and transparency are embraced instead of tightly controlled. item.title: France’s Colonial Legacy and the Contradictions of Republican Universalism
item.description:
In this long-form opinion essay, Rafael Poch de Feliu examines the deep historical roots of European, and particularly French, complicity with contemporary colonial violence, using the case of Gaza as a moral and political point of departure. The article argues that France’s Third Republic (1870–1940), often celebrated as a milestone of democratic freedoms and civic rights, simultaneously consolidated a brutal and explicitly racist colonial system. While republican liberties, secular education, and parliamentary life flourished within metropolitan France, the empire was governed through coercion, legal discrimination, and permanent states of exception.
Poch details how colonial domination was codified through mechanisms such as the Code de l’Indigénat, which denied basic rights to colonized populations and institutionalized forced labor, collective punishment, and racial hierarchy. item.title: Why People Are Drawn to Simple Compatibility Percentages in Relationships
item.description: Compatibility percentages have become popular again in apps, quizzes, and horoscopes, providing a seemingly objective number that can ease the uncertainty of early romance. Romance often involves ambiguity, where people interpret signals inconsistently, leading to anxiety. A single percentage offers reassurance by simplifying complex factors like values, communication styles, emotional safety, life stages, and stress tolerance into one digestible figure. Psychologically, this appeal stems from biases: anchoring makes the initial score shape perceptions of friction; precision bias lends undue credibility to a neat number; and confirmation bias leads people to seek supporting evidence while ignoring contradictions. item.title: Global Guinea Worm Cases Drop to 10 in 2025, Bringing Eradication Closer
item.description: The parasitic disease caused by the Guinea worm (Dracunculus medinensis) is nearing eradication, with only 10 human cases reported worldwide in 2025, according to the Carter Center. This marks a dramatic decline from 3.5 million cases across 21 countries when the eradication program began in 1986. The worm is transmitted through contaminated water containing copepods carrying larvae. Once ingested, the parasite migrates through the body and emerges painfully from the skin, typically in the legs or feet, potentially causing severe infections or disability. The remaining human cases in 2025 were reported in Chad, Ethiopia, and South Sudan. However, animal infections, particularly in dogs, continue to pose a challenge. Countries reporting animal cases include Chad, Mali, Cameroon, Angola, Ethiopia, and South Sudan. item.title: South Africa and Israel Expel Each Other's Top Diplomats Amid Rising Tensions
item.description: South Africa has declared Ariel Seidman, Israel's top diplomatic representative in Pretoria, persona non grata, giving him 72 hours to leave the country. The decision stems from repeated breaches of diplomatic protocol, including public statements from Israel's mission insulting South African President Cyril Ramaphosa and failure to notify authorities of visits by senior Israeli officials. This marks a significant escalation in tensions between Pretoria and Tel Aviv, which already have strained relations following South Africa's 2023 complaint against Israel at the International Court of Justice over alleged acts of genocide in Gaza. Israel responded in kind by declaring Shaun Edward Byneveldt, South Africa's top diplomat in Israel, persona non grata with the same 72-hour deadline. item.title: Los hackers adolescentes de Israel dan miedo
item.description: El vídeo presenta a un grupo de adolescentes israelíes con habilidades excepcionales en hacking y ciberseguridad. Demuestran su capacidad para encontrar vulnerabilidades en sistemas y aplicaciones, y exponen el potencial de la ciberseguridad en Israel y la necesidad de una formación adecuada para los jóvenes en este campo.

item.title: Rusia anuncia la detención en Dubái del presunto autor del atentado contra el subdirector del GRU
item.description:
Las autoridades rusas han anunciado la detención en Dubái del presunto autor del intento de asesinato contra Vladimir Alekseyev, subdirector de la Inteligencia Militar rusa (GRU), que fue tiroteado el pasado 6 de febrero en Moscú. Según el Servicio Federal de Seguridad (FSB), el detenido es Liubomir Korba, ciudadano ucraniano, arrestado gracias a una operación realizada en cooperación con las autoridades de Emiratos Árabes Unidos. Moscú sostiene que Korba actuó siguiendo instrucciones de los servicios de inteligencia ucranianos y que viajó a la capital rusa en diciembre de 2025 con el objetivo de cometer el atentado.
Tras abrir fuego contra el general en un edificio residencial del noroeste de Moscú, el sospechoso habría abandonado Rusia pocas horas después y volado a Dubái, donde finalmente fue localizado y detenido. Además, las autoridades rusas han informado de la detención de un cómplice en Moscú, Viktor Vasin, de nacionalidad rusa, y de la identificación de una tercera implicada,

item.title: Victoria demócrata contundente en Luisiana en un distrito favorable a Trump
item.description:
La demócrata Chasity Verret Martinez ha logrado una victoria amplia en una elección especial para la Cámara de Representantes del estado de Luisiana, imponiéndose con un 62 % de los votos frente al 38 % obtenido por el candidato republicano Brad Daigle. El resultado es especialmente relevante porque el distrito había sido ganado por Donald Trump por 13 puntos en las elecciones presidenciales de 2024, lo que llevó a los republicanos a considerar este escaño como una oportunidad clara para recuperarlo.
La elección especial se convocó tras la salida del anterior representante estatal, también demócrata, que fue nombrado comisionado del Departamento de Alcohol y Tabaco del estado por el gobernador republicano Jeff Landry. Aunque el escaño ya estaba en manos demócratas y, por tanto, no supone un cambio de partido, la magnitud de la victoria de Verret Martinez destaca por representar un giro de 37 puntos respecto a los resultados de 2024 en ese mismo distrito.

item.title: Las obras del acceso ferroviario del AVE en València descubren restos islámicos, medievales y napoleónicos
item.description:
Las obras del nuevo canal de acceso ferroviario del AVE a València y la remodelación de la estación Joaquín Sorolla han sacado a la luz un conjunto arqueológico de gran valor que abarca distintas etapas históricas de la ciudad. Aunque el área no estaba incluida inicialmente en zonas de vigilancia arqueológica, la Evaluación Ambiental estableció un seguimiento preventivo que ha permitido documentar hallazgos relevantes sin paralizar el proyecto.
Entre los descubrimientos destaca una necrópolis islámica de época andalusí, formada por enterramientos sencillos excavados directamente en la tierra y sin ajuar funerario. Los restos óseos aparecieron en niveles muy superficiales, junto a materiales cerámicos fragmentados y restos de vidrio. Este hallazgo se suma a otras necrópolis islámicas ya documentadas en barrios históricos como el Carmen, la Xerea o la Almoina, reforzando el conocimiento sobre la València musulmana.
También se han identificado estructuras hidráulicas medievales relacion

item.title: Mapa europeo del Censo 2021: distribución espacial de la población y sus características demográficas
item.description:
La herramienta interactiva del Censo 2021 en formato de mapa en cuadrícula, desarrollada por Eurostat, ofrece una visión detallada y comparable de la población en toda la Unión Europea a partir de celdas estadísticas homogéneas. A diferencia de los mapas administrativos tradicionales, este enfoque permite analizar la distribución real de la población sin las distorsiones que generan los límites municipales o regionales, facilitando así estudios más precisos sobre densidad, envejecimiento, movilidad y estructura demográfica.
El visor permite consultar indicadores clave como la densidad de población, la distribución por grupos de edad (menores de 15 años, población en edad activa y mayores de 65), el equilibrio entre hombres y mujeres, el índice de envejecimiento o las tasas de dependencia juvenil y de mayores. También incluye información sobre movilidad residencial entre 2020 y 2021, diferenciando entre cambios de residencia dentro del mismo país y movimientos procedentes del extranjer

item.title: Irán impone una nueva condena de siete años y medio de prisión a la activista y Nobel de la Paz Narges Mohammadi
item.description:
Un tribunal revolucionario iraní ha dictado una nueva condena contra la activista de derechos humanos y premio Nobel de la Paz 2023, Narges Mohammadi, imponiéndole siete años y medio de prisión por cargos de conspiración, colusión y propaganda contra el sistema. La sentencia, anunciada por su abogado Mostafa Nili, se suma a una larga lista de procesos judiciales contra la activista y constituye la décima condena que recibe desde 2021.
Según la resolución, Mohammadi ha sido condenada a seis años de cárcel por los cargos de congregación y colusión, y a un año y medio adicional por actividades propagandísticas. Como pena complementaria, se le ha impuesto una prohibición de dos años para salir del país. La sentencia fue dictada tras una audiencia celebrada en la sala primera del Tribunal Revolucionario de Mashad, adonde fue trasladada tras permanecer incomunicada durante casi dos meses.

item.title: Ismael Serrano reflexiona sobre el sectarismo político, la autocensura y el papel del cantautor en la sociedad actual
item.description:
Ismael Serrano concede una extensa entrevista en la que reflexiona sobre su trayectoria musical, el contexto político y social actual y el papel del artista comprometido en una época marcada por la polarización y la autocensura. El cantautor madrileño denuncia el creciente sectarismo dentro de la izquierda, que, según él, tiende a reprochar y excluir a quienes mantienen una visión crítica o matizada, exigiendo una adhesión ideológica sin fisuras. Aun así, Serrano se declara desencantado pero no desligado de la política, defiende el voto como herramienta democrática y rechaza equiparar a todos los políticos por igual.
A lo largo de la conversación, aborda la normalización de discursos crueles, especialmente en relación con la inmigración y la precariedad, y alerta sobre la pérdida de consensos básicos que antes parecían incuestionables. También reflexiona sobre el impacto de las redes sociales y los algoritmos, que fomentan la simplificación del mensaje, penalizan la reflexión y dificu

item.title: La rebelión de 1842: esclavos afroamericanos contra la esclavitud en la nación Cherokee
item.description:
La historia del Oeste estadounidense suele presentarse de forma simplificada, enfrentando a colonos blancos e indígenas, pero la realidad fue mucho más compleja. Un ejemplo poco conocido es la rebelión de esclavos afroamericanos que tuvo lugar en 1842 en territorio de la nación Cherokee, un episodio que cuestiona los relatos tradicionales sobre opresores y oprimidos.
A comienzos del siglo XIX, varias naciones indígenas del sureste de Estados Unidos —entre ellas los Cherokee— optaron por adoptar costumbres europeas para intentar sobrevivir a la presión del gobierno federal y de los colonos. Este proceso de asimilación, que les valió el nombre de las “Cinco Tribus Civilizadas”, incluyó la adopción del cristianismo, la agricultura de plantación y, de forma clave, la esclavitud de personas negras. Para las élites cherokee, poseer esclavos era tanto una fuente de riqueza como una prueba de “civilización” ante Washington.

item.title: Ayuso pide esperar a la justicia ante la denuncia contra el alcalde de Móstoles y critica la condena pública previa
item.description:
La presidenta de la Comunidad de Madrid, Isabel Díaz Ayuso, ha salido en defensa del alcalde de Móstoles, Manuel Bautista (PP), tras la acusación de una exconcejala que ha anunciado una denuncia por presunto acoso laboral y sexual. Durante un acto de clausura de la Academia de la Juventud Madrileña, Ayuso rechazó participar en lo que calificó como una condena pública anticipada y apeló a respetar los tiempos y garantías del sistema judicial antes de emitir juicios políticos o mediáticos.
Ayuso sostuvo que el Partido Popular no contribuirá a lo que considera un proceso de descrédito personal sin resolución judicial y advirtió del daño irreversible que, a su juicio, provocan las acusaciones difundidas antes de que se pronuncien los tribunales. En ese contexto, defendió que siempre hay tiempo para condenar si la justicia lo determina, pero no para reparar el honor de alguien si se le ha destruido previamente.

item.title: La Desbandá de Málaga y el uso propagandístico de imágenes falsas tras la masacre de 1937
item.description:
El artículo analiza uno de los episodios más trágicos y silenciados de la Guerra Civil Española: la conocida como La Desbandá de Málaga. El 8 de febrero de 1937, tras la caída de Málaga en manos de las tropas sublevadas, una enorme columna de civiles —entre 150.000 y 300.000 personas— huyó por la carretera costera hacia Almería. Durante la huida, fueron atacados desde el aire y el mar, provocando entre 3.000 y 5.000 muertes, lo que convierte este suceso en una de las mayores masacres del conflicto.
El texto se centra especialmente en el uso propagandístico de la fotografía durante y después de estos hechos. Explica cómo el bando sublevado intentó ocultar la masacre mediante la manipulación de la información y el uso engañoso de imágenes publicadas en la prensa de la época, como en el diario ABC de Sevilla. Estas fotografías mostraban a supuestas familias “liberadas” regresando alegremente a Málaga, cuando en realidad se trataba de civiles capturados durante la huida y obligados a volv

item.title: Los chinos ya no creen en el Sueño Americano
item.description: El vídeo analiza cómo la percepción del 'Sueño Americano' ha cambiado entre la comunidad china en Estados Unidos. Examina factores económicos, sociales y políticos que contribuyen a esta evolución, sugiriendo una creciente desilusión o un cambio en las aspiraciones de los chinos en EE. UU.

item.title: El Pentágono firma un contrato de 210 millones de dólares con Israel para la compra de municiones de racimo
item.description:
El Departamento de Defensa de Estados Unidos ha firmado discretamente un contrato de 210 millones de dólares con la empresa armamentística estatal israelí Tomer para la producción de nuevas municiones de racimo de artillería, conocidas como XM1208. Se trata de la mayor compra de armas realizada por EE. UU. a una empresa israelí en al menos los últimos 18 años, según registros federales, y se ha adjudicado sin concurso público bajo una excepción de “interés público”.
Las municiones de racimo están prohibidas por la Convención sobre Municiones en Racimo debido a su elevado impacto sobre la población civil, ya que dispersan submuniciones que con frecuencia no explotan y permanecen activas durante años. Aunque Estados Unidos, Israel y otras potencias militares no han firmado este tratado, el propio Pentágono había adoptado políticas para limitar el uso de modelos antiguos y desarrollar municiones con tasas de fallo inferiores al 1 %.

item.title: La hipocresía de los creadores de redes sociales: defienden la libertad mientras restringen su uso en sus familias y proponen regular la adicción digital
item.description:
El artículo critica la reacción de propietarios de grandes plataformas digitales como Elon Musk (X) y Pavel Dúrov (Telegram) ante las propuestas del Gobierno español, liderado por Pedro Sánchez, para endurecer la regulación contra la desinformación, la manipulación algorítmica y el acceso de menores a redes sociales. Estas medidas incluyen posibles responsabilidades penales para los CEO que no actúen ante contenidos ilegales o dañinos. Los dueños de las plataformas acusan de censura y autoritarismo, mientras que Santiago Abascal (Vox) apoya públicamente a Musk, priorizando a multimillonarios extranjeros sobre el debate sobre salud mental y democracia en España.
Se denuncia que las redes no son canales neutrales, sino sistemas diseñados para maximizar el tiempo de uso y el engagement mediante técnicas adictivas (scroll infinito, likes como inyecciones de dopamina, etc.), basadas en el capitalismo de la vigilancia descrito por Shoshana Zuboff. item.title: Aumento del 57 % de personas sin hogar en Buenos Aires en dos años según datos oficiales
item.description:
En la ciudad de Buenos Aires, la población sin hogar ha experimentado un fuerte incremento en los últimos años. Según el relevamiento oficial del Ministerio de Desarrollo Humano porteño, realizado en noviembre de 2025, hay 5.176 personas en esta situación, lo que supone un aumento del 57 % respecto a finales de 2023 (cuando eran 3.286) y del 28 % en un año (desde las 4.049 de 2024). De ellas, 1.613 viven en la vía pública y 3.563 en centros de asistencia estatales. La mayoría son hombres (83 %) de entre 19 y 59 años, y el 68 % lleva más de un año sin hogar. Los principales motivos citados son problemas laborales o económicos (42 %), conflictos familiares (34 %) y cuestiones de salud (7 %).
Un censo popular elaborado por más de 30 organizaciones sociales y religiosas eleva la cifra a 11.892 personas en 2025, un 64 % más que en 2019, aunque las metodologías difieren. item.title: Educar en el uso de la tecnología, no prohibir las pantallas
item.description:
El artículo sostiene que el debate sobre las pantallas y los menores está mal planteado, ya que se centra en demonizar el soporte tecnológico en lugar de analizar los contenidos, los comportamientos y, sobre todo, la responsabilidad educativa de los adultos. El autor recuerda que a lo largo de la historia nunca se ha culpado al soporte —papel, pergamino o imprenta— de los daños causados por determinadas ideas, sino al uso y a la interpretación de lo que se transmitía. Sin embargo, con las pantallas se ha optado por una simplificación que convierte la prohibición en la respuesta principal.
Reconoce que existen riesgos reales en internet, como el acoso, los contenidos sexuales no solicitados o determinadas dinámicas tóxicas en redes sociales. Pero subraya que estos problemas no son inherentes a las pantallas, sino a plataformas concretas, a comportamientos adultos irresponsables y a una clara falta de educación emocional y digital. item.title: Bertrand Ndongo increpa a Pilar Alegría durante su votación en Zaragoza
item.description:
La jornada electoral de las elecciones autonómicas de Aragón de 2026 ha estado marcada por un incidente protagonizado por el activista político Bertrand Ndongo durante el voto de la candidata socialista Pilar Alegría en Zaragoza. Alegría acudió a votar al IES Goya, en la capital aragonesa, en los primeros comicios autonómicos adelantados de la historia de la comunidad. Su presencia en el colegio electoral fue breve y su atención a los medios limitada, en parte debido a la actuación de Ndongo, exasesor de Rocío Monasterio (Vox) y conocido por sus acciones de confrontación en actos públicos.
Ndongo se presentó en el entorno del centro educativo y trató de incomodar a la candidata socialista formulándole preguntas de carácter provocador relacionadas con su trayectoria política y con supuestos escándalos. item.title: El cortometraje 'A Night at the Garden' como advertencia histórica ante el auge de la ultraderecha y la fragilidad de la democracia
item.description: El artículo analiza el cortometraje documental 'A Night at the Garden', nominado al Oscar en 2017, que utiliza exclusivamente material de archivo del mitin nazi celebrado el 20 de febrero de 1939 en el Madison Square Garden de Nueva York, donde se reunieron 20.000 personas simpatizantes del nazismo en Estados Unidos. Dirigido por Marshall Curry, el corto destaca la fusión de símbolos estadounidenses con iconografía nacionalsocialista, discursos antisemitas y la violencia ejercida contra un manifestante que irrumpió en el escenario, mientras niños observaban emocionados. El texto conecta este evento histórico con el contexto actual de 2026, reflexionando sobre el inicio de la presidencia de Trump en 2017, cuando el documental se interpretó como una advertencia, y las similitudes con el discurso de ultraderechas contemporáneas que señalan enemigos abstractos como la inmigración para explicar problemas sociales. item.title: El hermano de Jeffrey Epstein acusa a Trump de autorizar su asesinato en un aviso al FBI revelado en documentos del DOJ
item.description: Mark Epstein, hermano del fallecido financista Jeffrey Epstein, presentó en febrero de 2023 un aviso en línea al Centro Nacional de Operaciones de Amenazas del FBI, en el que alega que su hermano no se suicidó en su celda en 2019, sino que fue asesinado porque estaba a punto de revelar información comprometedora sobre personas poderosas. En el texto, con errores ortográficos incluidos, afirma explícitamente que cree que el entonces expresidente Donald Trump autorizó dicho asesinato. Mark Epstein proporcionó sus datos de contacto y confirmó a The Independent que nunca recibió respuesta ni seguimiento por parte del FBI ni de ninguna otra autoridad. El aviso fue reenviado internamente a un agente especial y forma parte de los millones de páginas de documentos sobre Epstein liberados por el Departamento de Justicia estadounidense en cumplimiento de la Ley de Transparencia de los Archivos Epstein.
